intro: Aspicarpa guaranitica, commonly known as the Guarani grape, is a climbing plant native to the Brazilian Pantanal region. It belongs to the family Violaceae and is characterized by its slender, twining stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically violet or blue in color. Its fruits are small, round berries that contain a single seed, and they are often consumed by local wildlife. Aspicarpa guaranitica plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, supporting various insect and bird species.
